I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:

Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: My skill of translating Yiddish has developed exponentially through this course. The goal of the course is, of course, to learn how to read Yiddish. Prof. Price puts emphasis on reading and learning Yiddish literary culture, which are both done exceptionally well.
I got better at polishing translations, and I was also able to learn more spoken Yiddish and grammar.
Developed my Yiddish reading comprehension and vocabulary, my translation skills, and with my ability to perform research in a foreign language.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course has mostly strengths. It provides a ton of practice and feedback on how to translate a wide variety of Yiddish texts, which I know feel an intermediate confidence in doing. It is engaging and Prof. Price is very accommodating and dedicated to his students. It's one weakness I felt was a lack of Yiddish "teaching". Josh will answer any questions and will do in-depth corrections of all of our translations, but the course does not necessarily give instruction on how to properly translate. Thus I found myself repeatedly making the same mistakes in my translations.

The students could guide what materials we covered in class, which was a big strength. The projects and assignments were fun and also allowed room for creativity. The instructor is also highly knowledgeable and hardworking and was able to guide us to anything we found interesting. The only way the class could be improved is if there were more of it!

Strengths: the readings were extremely diverse, both in terms of the backgrounds of the authors and the type of material we read (essays, articles, short stories, poetry). The homework assignments and presentations were a great way to ensure that we truly understood what we were reading, to develop the flexibility of word association in the language, and to make sure that we were really *learning* about Yiddish culture and not just reading an assortment of texts.
Weaknesses: I think that the readings could have been longer. Usually it would only take me 2-3 hours to translate something, which I would read first over the weekend., and I think it would be good if there were some way to incentivize students reading and translating more. Also, I did notice that for some students, their translation skills didn't really improve throughout the course. The course isn't really designed to teach students literary translation, as obviously the main focus is and should be teaching the language. But it might be interesting to have a "peer editing" component so students could improve each other's writing, rather than simply making sure that the translations are "accurate" by reading them aloud in class.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Prof Price did the best that was possible during COVID, and used breakout rooms and screen shares.

We could form different breakout groups to cover different paths (reading vs. speaking) which helped us customize our experience to our interests. There was also liberal screen sharing, which was fun. It would have been helpful for the university to provide reliable wifi to the participants, because people cut out sometimes, which is difficult to deal with in a language course.

I think the course worked well with Covid over Zoom. We didn't exactly take advantage of the special functions of online learning (I think it would have been cool, for example, to take advantage of Google docs collaboration in some way, though I'm not sure how), but I don't think it really would have been necessary.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, both for its obvious learning outcome (reading Yiddish) but also for its engagement with Yiddishkeyt more broadly
This course is so great to pursue your interests in whatever field through the lens of Yiddish! I loved this class, and if you have any interest in Yiddish at all, you should definitely try it!

Absolutely! Josh Price is really a pleasure to learn from--he gives clear feedback, and is very humble yet incredibly knowledgeable. Yiddish is a beautiful language and its culture is fascinating. It really is a must to take this class if you have a previous background in Yiddish, especially if you've taken Reading Yiddish as well.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: This class was a combination of small group translations, presentations, group translations, lectures.
